- Hypocritical. Just one example: Employees always encouraged to speak-up but employees who do end up being "council-ed" in the shadows. Environment of fear is inevitably created where people are afraid to speak up against behaviour/policies/ideas/processes that are detrimental to the company. At the same time, constant official promoting of speak-up culture with no decent voice from the employees create a false sense of security/achievement within higher management.
- Far too much power granted to managers to handle their subordinates' career, salary and even workload. No check-and-balance in that regard.
- Ground staff overworked consistently.

bp went through a considerable reorganisation in 2020-21 and it feels like things haven't settled since that disruption. There are a lot of good ideas floating around but the culture is too risk averse to be able to put things into action at the moment.
Although one of the aims of the re-org was to flatten out bp's hierarchy this has not been the reality and it seems like crucial decisions are being held in the hands of people who are too busy to understand the decision in order to make it. Currently it seems a little like junior level staff are being blamed for the consequences of inactivity and indecision at a senior level and that no one is holding these leaders to account. Career progression is very difficult and the barriers to progress don't seem like they'll be removed any time soon. A standard attitude that is held by staff is that you have to leave bp to progress in your career in order to return to the company at a more senior level which is obviously demotivating and reduces desire to remain at the company. Work activity is often set on what one leader has mentioned offhandedly in a meeting which results in a considerable waste of effort. This is due to attempting to address one concern without properly understanding its basis and then having to pivot to work on a different poorly detailed concern that was raised at another meeting. Agile has been implemented in an incomplete manner. It is expected that employees will work in line with an Agile methodology but there is no acceptance at a senior level to work to deliver an MVP and then iterate. It is expected that any solution should be perfect from release and this results in delays of multiple years for the release of solutions that are highly urgent to improve employee experience and retention.

pros: Insurance was great and they encouraged development and growth within the company and provided great programs and events to further development. Many fun events involving company-provided meals and snacks.
cons: Required every employee, on an annual basis, to complete a very time-consuming, duplicitous corporate compliance/documentation exercise disguised as a personal development or "Continuous Improvement" plan. They designed it to be an unusually and imo unnecessarily lengthy, detailed document that took an extraordinary amount of time and mental and emotional effort to maintain and update throughout the year. Perhaps this was out of an abundance of caution or to go above and beyond to leave no stone unturned and prevent further government action against them (sounds familiar from the last few years). I do know this resulted in every employee being forced to come up with a new way to reinvent the wheel every year and document you had done so - even if the wheel did not need reinventing and current processes were working very well. It was a very intense, often-pointless project that often made it very challenging to satisfactorily perform regular role responsibilities. This was all started as a save-face to appease the government after the very-tragic oil spill in 2010 but there seemed to be very little concern about the impact on the employee's morale and ability to perform well. IMHO, the leadership could have designed these new compliance requirements in a way that was more manageable for each employee in light of the already-high requirements of completing our daily job deliverables. I get it. As we've seen with Covid responses, etc, it's human nature to want to overreact without considering impacts on all sides using a cost/benefit balancing test. To jump right to the most restrictive measure possible without first considering less-restrictive, more narrow measures designed to specifically address the issue and nothing more.

The latest layoffs were done in an opaque manner.
